cards.front: What are the three standard basis vectors in 3D?
cards.back:
• \( \hat{i} \): \( [1, 0, 0] \) - unit vector in x-direction
  • \( \hat{j} \): \( [0, 1, 0] \) - unit vector in y-direction
  • \( \hat{k} \): \( [0, 0, 1] \) - unit vector in z-direction

cards.front: How is a 3D linear transformation represented as a matrix?
cards.back:
A 3x3 matrix where:

  • Column 1: where \( \hat{i} \) lands
  • Column 2: where \( \hat{j} \) lands
  • Column 3: where \( \hat{k} \) lands

These 9 numbers completely describe the transformation.

cards.front: How do you apply a 3x3 matrix to a vector \( [x, y, z] \)?
cards.back:
Multiply each coordinate by its corresponding column and sum:

\( x \cdot (\text{column 1}) + y \cdot (\text{column 2}) + z \cdot (\text{column 3}) \)

Same pattern as 2D, extended to three terms.
